learning_outcomes.description: Recognise the interdisciplinary nature of modern science, including some of the similarities and differences across a range of discipline areas.
Explain the importance of modelling in science by demonstrating the skills required to produce and analyse such models.
Apply fundamental mathematical techniques that are important to problems across a range of scientific discipline areas.
Explain key introductory concepts in computer science, design and write simple computer programs in the language Python, and interpret the output of these programs.
Describe and discuss some philosophical accounts of scientific reasoning.
Communicate responses to quantitative and science-based problems in a correct, logical and scientifically appropriate style.

Develop an awareness of the importance of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander and global Indigenous Peoples’ values, cultures and knowledges and how this relates to being a contemporary scientist.

assessments.due_date:
Each week at the time of your applied class.

For those students with special permission to complete task sheets independently, submissions are due at 1pm on the following Monday (at which time solutions will be released).
assessments.task_description:
You should attend your applied class either in-person (in-person enrolled students) or on Zoom (external students). For each applied class you will be provided with a task sheet containing relevant activities similar in style to SCIE1000 assessments. If you are unwell then DO NOT attend your in-person applied class - see extension information below.

Each applied class will be marked out of 1. To earn 1 point, you must participate fully in the activities by:

  1. Arriving on-time and staying on task throughout the class.
  2. Writing solutions to the problems you are working so that the teaching staff can note your progress.
  3. Participating in peer-to-peer discussions when asked.
  4. Explaining your working on problems to demonstrate your understanding.
  5. Completing any other relevant task as directed by the teaching staff (for example, the philosophy applied class may have different participation requirements than the other applied classes).

Your score for the applied class component will be the sum of your marks from the 12 graded classes, or 10, whichever is smaller. This means your maximum applied class score is 10 and you may achieve this by earning 10, 11 or 12 marks in the 12 graded classes.

Applied class scores will be uploaded to Blackboard the week after the class runs. It is your responsibility to check these marks and contact teaching staff via the procedure outlined on Blackboard if you have any concerns or think that a mark has been missed.

assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible as task sheets are completed in class (and solutions are released at the due time for those with special permission to complete task sheets independently).
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description: This assignment will assess the degree to which students have reached the learning outcomes in the philosophy component of SCIE1000 by requiring them to write an essay discussing aspects of the scientific method.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The essay must be submitted electronically through Blackboard by the due date and time. The plagiarism detection software TurnItIn will be used to check submissions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Students will develop and demonstrate their skills in writing a Python program, as well as demonstrating their ability to communicate science in a way that is appropriate for a prescribed target audience. Along with the Python program, students will prepare and submit a short screen capture video explaining their work. The assignment will be given within a specific scientific context, and students will use scientific information and mathematical models within their Python program. The assignment will assess the degree to which students have reached the learning outcomes in the programming and scientific communication components of SCIE1000.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Note that there are two separate links for submitting your solutions. Your computer program must be submitted electronically in .py format through one link while your screen capture video is submitted through a separate Blackboard link. Both must be submitted by the due date and time (please check the task sheet for guidance in preparing your submission). Plagiarism detection software will be used to check the originality of your code.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
All students will be allowed to bring a UQ approved calculator to the exam. For more information and UQ policy click here. The end-of-semester examination is closed-book. However, you may bring in a single, double-sided sheet of A4 paper containing any information you may find useful for the exam. This information can be hand-written or computer generated (or a mixture of both) - there are no restrictions.

The End of Semester Examination will be an in-person, paper-based exam for all students.

Internally enrolled students

The final exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam. Students will sit the exam at the St Lucia Campus.

Externally enrolled students

The final exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam. UQ Examinations will contact students directly to confirm arrangements. You will either sit the exam at the St Lucia campus (if you live within 200km radius of the campus) or will be directed to nominate an exam centre by a certain date. 

Please ensure you update your semester address in Si-net at the start of the semester.

One reminder will be sent and students who fail to nominate an exam centre and will be automatically assigned to the St Lucia campus. Late nominations will not be accepted.
